questions: Q. 4. Which is the innermost membrane in meningitis?
answers: Ans. Pia meter.

questions: Q. 5. What constitutes brain stem?
answers: Ans. The medulla oblongata, pons varolii and mid brain are collectively called the brain stem.

questions: Q. 6. How diameter of an axon affects the speed of an impulse?
answers: Ans. The impulse travels slower in a thinner fibre than in a thicker one.

questions: Q. 7. What is arbor vitae?
answers: Ans. The potential difference in charge on either side of the plasma membrane of a resting neuron is called as the resting potential.

questions: Q. 11. What are meninges?
answers: Ans. It performs two functions: (i) The stimuli are passed from and to the brain through the spinal cord. (ii) It is the centre of spinal reflex action. (Any two)

questions: Q. 20. Name the longest cranial nerve.
answers: Ans. Vagus nerve is the longest cranial nerve.

questions: Q. 21. What does the term stimulus mean?
answers: Ans. A stimulus is sudden change in the environment which is strong enough to excite the nerve or muscle or organism as a whole.

questions: Q. 22. What is the nature of the nerve impulses?
answers: Ans. The nature of the nerve impulse is electrochemical.

questions: Q. 23. How is the shape of the cornea maintained?
answers: Ans. An aquenous fluid called ‚Äòaqueous humour‚Äô supplies nutrients to the cornea and thus maintain its shape.

questions: Q. 24. Name the exposed, transparent part of the eyeball.
answers: Ans. Cornea is the exposed, transparent part of the eyeball.

questions: Q. 25. Name the bones which help in hearing.
answers: Ans. Malleus, incus and stapes.

questions: Q. 26. Why does a red coloured cloth look black in the evening?
answers: Ans. The red coloured cloth appear black in the evening because only rod cells function in the dim light.

questions: Q. 27. What is the function of eustachian tube?
answers: Ans. Eustachian tube acts as a ventilator and helps in equalising air pressure on the two sides of the tympanic membrane.

questions: Q. 28. Name the fluid in which the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear floats.
answers: Ans. Perilymph.

questions: Q. 29. What is otolith?
answers: Ans. Small Particles of calcium salts in the ears of vertebrates are called otolith

questions: Q. 30. why blind spot in the eye is devoid of vision?
answers: Ans. It is due to the absence of photoreceptors cells, rods and cones in that region.

questions: Q. 31. What is binocular vision?
answers: Ans. When both the eyes can be focused simultaneously on a common object it is called binocular vision ùëí. ùëî., humans.

questions: Q. 32. What are ceruminous glands?
answers: Ans. These are modified sweat glands found in ear, which secrete a waxy substance-the cerumen which prevents the entry of foreign bodies into the ear.

questions: Q. 33. What is a yellow spot?
answers: Ans. It is an area of retina in a human eye which contains only cone cells and no rod cells.

questions: Q. 34. Which structure in the inner ear contains hair cells that act as auditory receptors?
answers: Ans. The organ of corti contains hair cells.

questions: Q. 35. Name the three layers of cells contained in the retina from inside to outside.
answers: Ans. Ganglion cells, bipolar cells and photoreceptor cells.

questions: Q. 36. Name the three divisions of the bony labyrinth which is formed by the cochlear membrane.
answers: Ans. (i) upper scala vestibuli (ii) middle scala media (iii) lower scala tympani

questions: Q. 37. Name the jelly like fluid present in eye ball which cannot be replaced in significant quantity.
answers: Ans. Vitreous humour.

questions: Q. 38. Why cornea can be transplanted easily?
answers: Ans. Eornea can be transplanted as it non-vascular laver.
